Hillary Clinton Emails

                        No work-related messages had been withheld or destroyed, she said. 

            By 
Rachael Bade

09/03/15, 06:04 PM EDT

                Updated 09/03/15, 06:45 PM EDT

                Getty
Cheryl Mills, a trusted Hillary Clinton staffer who oversaw the release of her emails, told House investigators that no work-related messages had been withheld or destroyed to keep them from public eyes — and Mills said she never knowingly mishandled classified information, a source familiar with her testimony told POLITICO.
Mills, Clinton’s former chief of staff at the State Department, told the House Select Committee on Benghazi in a closed-door session Thursday that she did not withhold any federal records when she helped oversee the production of thousands of Clinton's emails to the Department. Nor did she know of anyone who did.
Mills' testimony is perhaps the highest-profile interview the panel has conducted since its probe began a year ago. And unlike some of the other staff interviewed, Mills had a direct role in combing through Clinton's emails before they were handed over to the government or destroyed. 
The longtime family lawyer for the Clintons, who defended Bill during his impeachment days, worked alongside Clinton’s lead lawyer David Kendall of Williams & Connolly to oversee the process whereby they selected which emails should be saved from a homemade personal server Clinton used during her State Department tenure. After the Clinton team finished scouring the messages, they had the server wiped clean, deleting the rest of the contents.
According to the source close to Mills, two employees at Denver-based technology company Platte River Networks originally pulled the messages from the server, and a few lawyers under Kendall and Mills sifted through the messages to pull anything they thought could constitute a federal record.

2016

            By 
Rachael Bade

Mills testified that they weren’t trying to hide anything when Clinton decided to wipe the server and that they were over inclusive in what they thought might be a work-related message. Clinton has said the remaining, erased correspondence were "personal" in nature. 
Panel Republicans are skeptical that Clinton preserved all her work related emails — particularly after they discovered this spring about a dozen undisclosed Clinton emails in a separate set of messages they received from her longtime ally Sid Blumenthal. Those emails were work related, they argue, and should have been included. They suspect there could be more that didn't make the cut before the server was erased. 
“Chairman Gowdy is concerned with ensuring the Committee has a complete and responsive record, and understanding any facts or events that may have led to the committee not having a complete record,” said Jamal Ware, committee spokesman. 
The testimony comes just a few hours after a lawyer for Clinton’s go-to IT staffer Bryan Pagliano said he’d take the Fifth and refuse to answer potentially self-incriminating questions from the committee. The panel subpoenaed him in hopes of learning more about the server set-up the former State Secretary exclusively used for work, which was under tech guru Pagliano’s charge.
 Clinton’s use of private email as the nation’s top diplomat has created significant headwinds for her current White House campaign, hurting her in the polls as some call into question her trustworthiness and transparency. Government officials are supposed to use official email to capture public records, but Clinton's unusual setup seems to have challenged that notion. State Department policy in effect at the time Clinton was in office called for the "day-to-day" work of the department to be done on official accounts and systems. Clinton's aides have argued that use of personal email was not exclusively prohibited.
While probing a batch of the more than 35,000 emails Clinton turned over, an intelligence community watchdog found messages it argues were or should have been classified at the time they were created — never left on an unsecured server. The State Department has classifed 188 messeges but refuted the notion that they were classified when Cilnton and her top aides like Mills fowarded them around on an unsecured network. 



            By 
Marc Caputo

Still, the intelligence community referred the matter to the FBI, which is probing the special email arrangement to learn if top secret information was ever put at risk. 
While Mills no longer works directly under Clinton, she still sits on the philanthropic Clinton Foundation board and advises the family from time to time, including on personal matters like closing on a house. She has a reputation for being blunt with a family that's used to being treated like royalty.
And lawmakers in attendance say she was certainly charming. She emerged from her nearly 10-hour interview smiling and laughing with Chairman Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.). She stood beside the South Carolina Republican and lawmakers from both sides of the committee, and thanked them for their “professionalism" and "respect" and "the work they're doing."
“Obviously, the tragedy that happened in Benghazi was about more than what’s happening in this room: it was about the loss of individuals who were dear to the State Department and dear to this country," she said. "And we honor them by remembering what happened and doing our best to ensure that that doesn’t happen again, so I’m grateful for the chance I had to visit with the committee today.”
Gowdy, likewise, thanked her for coming, said she answered every question they asked and told reporters that the committee would not be giving a read-out from the session. Lawmakers refused to answer questions about what happened in the room, and Mills likewise did not give interviews.
The cordial atmosphere was a surprisingly stark contrast from the way Blumenthal’s deposition ended, with the witness saying the GOP asked him mostly about political items and how much he made, and Republicans questioning his integrity for passing the nation’s chief diplomat information unvented intelligence on Libya.
Rep. Trey Gowdy is pictured. | Getty 
"The dialogue was professional and fact-centric, and the members of the Benghazi committee on our side are going to treat the conversation as if its classified,” was all Gowdy said. “I’m not going to be able to answer any of your questions.”
Top panel Democrat Elijah Cumming (D-Md.), also in the same gaggle, did not accuse the panel of playing politics — though, hours before, he told reporters he felt the probe had “turned into an [attempted] derailment of the Clinton nomination.”
Mills told the Benghazi panel she was not aware if anyone raised red flags about Clinton’s use of a personal email system at State — nor did anyone specifically approve the private server that she knew of, according to the source familiar with her testimony. 
Mills said she was not involved in setting up the initial server, nor was she part of the decision to have it stored at Platte River Networks, a small start-up that was reported to have stored servers in a bathroom closet at one point. 
Mills was one of several top State officials who forwarded Clinton a number of emails that the intelligence community now believes should have been classified. But she testified that she never knowingly mishandled classified documents.
Messages came to Mills and her colleagues, often from foreign service officers out in the field around the world, on two different computers: one, a classified computer system that was protected and would have prevented the forwarding of any message outside a secure network; the other, an unclassified machine, which would have allowed staff to forward the messages. 
In many instances, Mills received messages from the unclassified networks and forwarded them along to Clinton, although some of those messages were deemed classified after the fact.
She also said she never moved emails from a classified to an unclassified system. In an old 2010 email exchange released this week, Jake Sullivan, Clinton’s top policy staffer who will testify before the panel Friday, explained to Clinton that he couldn’t simply pull information off the classified computer and send it over an unsecured network, for example.
Mills also reiterated to the panel what Clinton’s camp has consistently said about the Benghazi attack: She said she knows of no “stand down order” following the attacks, nor has she any knowledge of the U.S. moving weapons or knowing of other countries moving weapons to Libyan rebels. Conservatives suspected that the weapons used to overrun the compound that fateful Sept. 11, 2012 day may have come from a covert smuggling operation that went awry. 
Following the attack, Mill testified there was no cover up or attempt to mislead the American public about what happened. Shortly after the 2012 attacks, US Ambassador to the UN Susan Rice on national television blamed the attack on a protest against an anti-Islam documentary — a suggestion the intelligence community later said was false since it was a plotted terrorist attack. 
Mills said they didn’t know it was solely a terrorist attack until Sept. 21.
As for her own use of personal email, Mills testified, according to the source, that she used work email “overwhelmingly” and almost only used personal email when she was overseas, at home at night or when their State email otherwise didn’t work. The source previewing the testimony also said she copied her State.gov addresses most of the time when she did go for personal email. 
Mills has come under scrutiny for turning down a federal judge's request that she and Huma Abedin sign an affidavit swearing that she handed in all her federal documents. She testified, however, that she did turn them all in.
Josh Gerstein contributed to this story.

                                            By 
Michael Kazin


                                            By 
Rich Lowry


                                            By 
Barney Frank

description: No work-related messages had been withheld or destroyed, she said.
title: What Cheryl Mills told Benghazi investigators
